title: 105_s1282
content: The Act may be cited as the "Peopling of America Museum Act". The history of the United States is largely about how it was populated, with various groups making unique contributions to American culture. The diversity of the population has led to the vitality of the country. The Smithsonian Institution operates multiple museums, galleries, a zoo, and research facilities. The absence of a national institution dedicated to presenting the history of the peopling of the United States limits the ability of existing museums to fully showcase the diverse population and rich cultures of the country. This restricts the citizens' understanding of the varied heritage derived from the unique histories of many peoples. The establishment of a Peopling of America Museum will educate citizens on the diverse cultural heritage of the United States, derived from the unique histories of many peoples from many lands. The Act defines key terms such as Chairperson, Committee, Director, and Museum. The National Museum for the Peopling of America is established under the Act. The National Museum for the Peopling of America is established within the Smithsonian Institution to promote knowledge of the diverse groups that make up the United States, illustrate their interactions, and explain how their experiences contribute to a unified national identity. The Museum includes exhibits on the historical population process of the United States and a center for research and scholarship. The National Museum for the Peopling of America is a center for research, scholarship, and preservation of artifacts related to the diverse population of the United States. It also serves as a venue for public education programs and the development of a standardized index of documents and artworks. The National Museum for the Peopling of America aims to provide access to various collections from different sources, including Federal agencies, museums, universities, individuals, and foreign institutions. It also includes a folklife center, a center for promoting mutual understanding among different groups, an oral history library, and a visitor center. The National Museum for the Peopling of America includes a visitor center providing orientation guides, training for museum professionals, and testing new museum technologies. The Museum will be located in a Smithsonian facility near the National Mall in DC, and the Board of Regents may construct appropriate facilities. The Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution appoints key personnel for the Museum, who must be qualified for their roles. Certain civil service laws may not apply to the appointment of the Director and 5 employees. The Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution appoints key personnel for the Museum, who must be qualified for their roles. Certain civil service laws may not apply to the appointment of the Director and 5 employees, including fixing their pay without following standard classification and pay rate regulations. SEC. 7. ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON AMERICAN CULTURAL HERITAGE. An advisory committee called the "Advisory Committee on American Cultural Heritage" has been established with 15 members appointed by the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Members must have expertise in fields related to cultural heritage and reflect the diversity of the United States citizens. The "Advisory Committee on American Cultural Heritage" has 15 members appointed by the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Initial appointments must be made within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Committee, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and meet at least twice a year. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Advisory Committee on American Cultural Heritage, consisting of 15 members appointed by the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, advises on policies and programs affecting the Museum. The Committee selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. Non-federal members are compensated for their service. Members of the Advisory Committee on American Cultural Heritage, appointed by the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, serve without compensation. They are allowed travel expenses at authorized rates while away from their homes or regular places of business. The Chairperson of the Committee may appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson can also determine their compensation independently. The Chairperson of the Committee may appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. The rate of pay for the executive director and staff cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Chairperson can also procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of level V pay. The rate of pay for the executive director and staff of the Committee cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule.
